channel.title: Php file
channel.description:
Someone uploaded this php file on http://lordbost.com/upload/upload.php (password protected for the moment, some retard tried uploading the file again.) after changing the file type to gif and png. I have deleted the files now, but im just wondering if anyone can take a look at the file and tell me what it does.
[br][br][size=1]Posted on: November 17, 2009, 03:08:38 am[/size][hr]I have temporary password protected the upload site..
EDIT: view the file here http://lordbost.com/random/r57.phps

item.title: Php file
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:15, topic:314523”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=410999.msg3032289#msg3032289 date=1258478172]
It’s easy, just set everything that is uploaded so it can’t be executed. How hard is that?
[/quote]
what i did for my upload folder:

AddType application/x-httpd-php-source php
AddType text/plain html

in .htaccess[/quote]

I’d do it for .cgi, .php5 and .php4 files too, just to be on the safe side.

Read full topic

item.description:
@lawl wrote:

Moparisthebest:

It’s easy, just set everything that is uploaded so it can’t be executed. How hard is that?

what i did for my upload folder:

AddType text/plain html

in .htaccess

item.title: Php file
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

runescape3dude:

omfg why the hell is everyone on this site so obsessed with avast?!

I just suggested avast because abraham proved that it searches for shell scripts. I’m sorry Unhandled, I assume that everyone runs a dedicated server. I personally would prefer to install av software which has a massive database of these files rather than writing a rubbish code that uses complicated checks to determine if the script is a shell script.

There shouldn’t be the problem of shell scripts in the first place though. Just tighten the security around filetypes and if someone does manage to bypass it, just disable PHP execution in the upload directory. Or, store the files in an unknown directory and use a database to map the virtual location to the real location and make the reader of the real file simply read and echo it - then there’s no way the code can execute.

Read full topic

item.title: Php file
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Why the hell do you need an anti virus to remove a php file? Moreover, how the fuck are you supposed to install Avast (or any other AV) in a shared hosting environment likely running Linux?

Read full topic

item.title: Php file

item.title: Php file
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

Yeah it’s a shell script. Let’s people change and view any unprotected file on your server and usually comes with extra features like MySQL access. If you install a virus scanner on your server it can just remove it automatically (namely avast).

Read full topic

Why don’t you put the php file on your site and change the extension to .phps?[/quote]

done.

http://lordbost.com/random/r57.phps
